Looking at your songs list, it seems to me that you're free to do whatever you want to is the absolute milestone in your work. It marks the end of your early amateur efforts and blasts into utter professionalism. It sounds like any of your 2018 songs. How did this giant leap forward happen?

what you might be hearing, in the recording, is more of a willingness to pursue complete vocal harmonies. Typically what happened previously, when doing a full length song, is, by the time i get the regular vocal all done and set, i have no energy left to actually deal with all the vocal harmonies. Because it is a lot of work to do vocal harmonies. but around 2015 i started recognizing the importance of following through with that, and i prioritized it much more, and developed some effecient procedures for working through this. and almost every recording since then has used a significant amount of vocal harmonies. however it should be mentioned that the writing for that song was mostly done in 2010

As an unknown musician which tries to make good music to eventually become a little less unknow, I was wondering how do you create such unexpected but cool chords progressions. Does it require a lot of harmonic knowledge?

it helps to have a lot of harmonic experience. But, there's more to the story. If you just have a lot of harmonic experience, you're probably going to be thinking about the chords too much. What kind and/or how much vocal training have you had?

never understood most vocal training, because i found breathing to be so connected to thought, i've always found it difficult to really control your breathing/air directly. so vocal triaining mostly never made sense to me in that way. so i was stuck on my own, and yet i sounded terrible. so that left me to figure out what to do. i quickly realized that there is a phenomenon at play here which is very similar to acting. you have to convince your inner-most mind to actually believe in the things you are communicating. A neat hack i found was to improvise the lyrics. i always seemed to sound much better when the words were genuinely made up at the time i'm singing them, instead of scripted. and if they are scripted, you have to ask a lot of similar questions that an actor would ask, about your character and your situation that you are trying to envoke. but aside from that, i also found out later that simply the more time singing makes you better. then much later on, a voice doctor told me that clearing your throat is bad, so i stopped doing that, and i also picked up a boring warm up exercise which i do on morning walks

how do you decide on what you call your songs/videos? for example, what were you debating about when you were trying to decide the title of "got some money"?

it was written in my song list as "got some money, got some cash, i'm rich and now i'm sad", but that's obviously too much for a real title. more reasonable titles would be "got some money, got some cash", then i quickly settled on "money (cash)" and i assumed that is what it would be for most of the time i was writing it. Then i decided to go even simpler for the song title ('money') because it seemed the strongest. How do you suggest I study rhythm? A lot of the melodies I try to make are rhythmically simple, repetitive, and boring

divide a bar into 4 beats. then divide each beat into 4 subdivisions. so you'll have 16 ticks per bar. Experiment with putting 1 note in the bar at different places. try putting it in every different place and sing it with a metronome and see what it sounds like. Now try putting 2 notes in the bar, in various places

hi, what happens when i makin a song but i make the melody but i forget to put words to it, but now i am at the melody and i don't know how to figure out what words to attach? did i fuck it up?

first, you must try to convince the song you are actually NOT trying to write it. make up a contract agreement that you and the song can sign, that says "i am NOT trying to 'write' this song, and will not make any attempts to do so!" and you and the song both sign it, and maybe you'll have some fine print located somewhere near the bottom of your left shoe or something. Then, as you sit down casually next to your melody, 'NOT' appearing to have any intention or desire to write the song, .... just begin trying phrases and sentences with the melody. don't worry about what's "good" or not yet, just start saying anything that comes to mind, with that melody. You will automatically start getting a feel for what the mechanics are (lyrically) of this melody. you'll see which kinds of words and phrases seem to always want to go in certain parts. and you'll just be internalizing the melody subconsciously, in the linguistic part of your mind. Then, put that aside, and just tell a story in your own words of what this melody is. When did you think of it? how did it make you feel? describe anything you know or feel about this melody and its origins. Sometimes you can even catch a glimpse of the exact essence of what the melody seems to be saying, even if it's the totally wrong number of words or syllables and has no physical resemblence to the shape or size of the melody. if you get this, definitely write it down. just try to PARAPHRASE (non-musically, in normal non-lyrical language) exactly what you think the melody seems to feel like it's saying. Now at this point the song will probably start to think you are trying to write it, with all the effort you've been putting in, so you will probably need an updated contract to assure everyone even more clearly that you are 'NOT' 'TRYING' to 'write' the song. then after that it's pretty much a waiting game. if you can stay calm and be patient enough for the song to forget you are trying to write it, that's when it's gonna happen

this is a more general question about writing, not necessarily lyrics, but any form of creative piece. when you are stuck on a part, how do you get rid of or work around the writers block? 

i feel like anytime i really get into any personal projects that involve words, i end up stopping because of writers block and never return to it again, no matter how much i previously liked it

basically what you want to do is open up the project and then act so calm and natural that the project eventually forgets you are there. the writing doesn't want to happen if it feels like it's being watched. it wants to be able to blow your mind, and surprise you, which is really difficult for it to do if you're staring directly at it. but if you open up the project and act naturally next to it, EVENTUALLY the project will calm down and forget you're there, and then the whole thing starts writing itself

I've noticed you have lots of sheets and charts for some of the stuff you write. how important do you finding writing music down on paper to be?

I have a traditional music background and a bachelors degree in music but when I'm actually doing stuff I ~like~ to do like song writing and recording little tunes I hardly ever write anything down minus the words and chords

if you're brave enough to believe you can remember the exact melody, then that's fine. i don't like to take any chances with that. i've watched people come up with a brand new awesome idea, and then play the same thing for me again tomorrow and the melody has changed and they don't realize it, and the original was definitely better. Because new song ideas are so new, you haven't heard them very much, so you are likely to forget exactly how it went. i am not comfortable trusting that the next time i look at it i'll remember the exact melody. so i must document it exactly. Whether this is done with notation or not, it doesn't really matter to me. it can be done with recording references, and nowadays i always use recording references, because we live in such a digital world. but for a long time i was using handwritten notation. The only times i ever do it with notation is when i have no instrument near me. i used to go to the library and put in earplugs and write songs that way. nowadays, when writing songs at the keyboard, i just make recorded references and cite them in the lyric sheet. The same goal is accomplished: to exactly document the lyric, melody, and chords

I feel like my methodical, trial-and-error approach to creating music is vastly inferior. I study my favorite songs' chord progressions, melodies, timbres, rhythms, etc., to see what makes a song "good", and I use these conclusions to aid me in my songwriting process. But I feel like the end result isn't truly original, not inspired by something "beyond this world".

When I sit down to make music, I feel like I'm forcing it. It doesn't feel authentic, and it doesn't sound original. I feel like I'm just ripping off my favorite artists. Part of me thinks that I haven't studied/practiced enough to convert inspiration into originality. I've only covered a few dozen  songs i n-depth. Another part of me thinks that I don't have a creative/original mind, and never will.

I know that you aren't omniscient, and this isn't an easy topic. But I would be truly grateful for any advice you have for me, based on the thoughts that I'm having.

from what you're saying, you say you catch yourself 'forcing' it. This makes me think you want it really really badly. Which makes sense. who wouldn't, after seeing what magic can be found in music. I think i have good and bad news for you. the good news is, it IS that magical, it IS other worldly, and pretty much everything about the way it functions best, makes it seem like it literally came from somewhere else. The bad news is ....... it reminds me of something you see in movies where the only way you get it is if you can actually stop thinking about it. And this is actually a problem i can sympathize with, because, if you want it so so so bad, how could you possibly stop thinking about it? but i think ultimately this IS what's going to happen. you WILL be able to calm down. whether you want to wait patiently or whether you keep kicking and screaming in desperation for a while and eventually exhaust yourself, and after all that is said and done, it WILL come. this may seem hard to believe but it wants you every bit as bad as you want it. it just really really needs you to be as open minded as possible, in order for it to feel comfortable arriving, because that's when it knows it can blow your mind the most. which, presumably, is what you've requested

i have good news and bad news. The good news is, i have the (ref: https://billwurtz.com/i%20like.pdf"target="_blank">original chart of when i wrote it, all on paper, years before i ever recorded it. The bad news is, it's not guaranteed to be entirely accurate because when i record a song, i am potentially allowed to invoke the 'suck' clause and change some of the details IF i thought it sucked. but the good news is, i'm looking at the chart right now and it seems extremely accurate. the bad news is that the end was re-written (not shown on this chart) but the good news is that the new ending is only 4 bars, in replacement of 27 bars on the chart, and those new 4 bars, if they were written in this chart language, would not have shown any chords, it would be notated as rap only, in a similar notation language to the 27 bar ending you do see. so you wouldn't have seen any chords from the chart there anyway. The bad news of course, is that for sections like that, in this chart language, you never see any chords, and chordal decisions for those types of sections are made during the recording. However the good news is that the only other part like this would be the intro, and i think i actually did not use any chords there in the recording either. However the bad news is, for that new 4 bar section which occurs in the recording but not the chart, there IS chordal information there (arranged when recording) that would certainly NOT be reflected in the chart. Also the other bad news is that the final recording is not guaranteed to be done in the same key as the chart, BUT the good news is, in this case it actually was. The good news is, i'm pretty sure i must have some sort of document somewhere that indicates the writing of those last 4 bars, either a written update or a recorded writing demo, but the bad news is i can't seem to find it and now i think it doesn't exist, and it seems more likely that i was feeling brave enough to actually re-write a 4 bar ending on the spot, in the recording session, which is a rare occurence but not impossible. The good news is i just found the (ref: i-like-p2.jpg"target="_blank">written update which contains the last line written at the end. and i can say for certain that you are supposed to cross out the entire line before "v2" and also cross out everything up until that new line. the only reason i probably didn't cross it out is because i knew i was already recording it so i didn't need to make note of that change. but i can assure you that i never intended for that additional 4 bars to be in addition to the other 27. they are intended to replace everything from "get it" and after. so with some assembly required, you can take the original page 1 from <a href="https://billwurtz.com/i%20like.pdf"target="_blank">here, then cross out the last 27 bars and REPLACE it with the last 4 bars of <a href="i-like-p2.jpg"target=)_blank)this page. and the extra 27 bars remains as a bonus alternate ending, which should NOT include the final 4

How do you learn to figure out what different chords are by ear?

go through about 50 of your favorite songs, and identify each chord with brute force. quickly unpause/pause (or nowadays you can edit to loop a tiny fraction of audio very quickly) and just pick it out note by note and put it together. write down all the chords to a song (in time, with bar lines, etc.)..... once you do this for about 30 or 40 songs, i think you will find that you don't have to search for the individual notes anymore. ... maybe not even pause it at all. After about 100 more songs, you probably won't even have to listen to the song, you will be able to do it from memory. after about 1000 songs, you will probably be able to hear someone singing the melody for a song you have never heard before, without hearing the chords, and figure out what the chords should be. after 10,000 songs, you should be able to play chords along with them on the first try, never having heard the song before, and have them think you already knew the song

When I'm in the middle of completing a hard portion of a goal, I often have a strong urge in the middle of hardship or annoyance to run away from the task and do something pleasant. It hits repeatedly, and accompanies a virtual titanium wall that starts to prevent me from moving forward and even if I can stand to get past it I work very slowly. If I cant stand it, I abandon the process. How can I better deal with or eliminate this pernicious feeling?

i think it's time to have a discussion about it. first, harken back to when the project was first started, and recall what it's really all about, and why you are doing it. this often helps. And the other thing you can do is discuss the specific procedure. If you are hitting a wall, it often means that you don't actually know exactly what you are supposed to do next. sometimes you think you know, but you don't actually know, and this can be a reason for things being slow. discussing things usually helps a lot

how do you find/make all of the cool instruments in your music? i have a hard time finding good instruments to use.

here's a good trick i use: shorten the release and the attack. most sounds you will find, to start off, are a total mess, with a really long attack and release. probably meant for someone who doesn't really play the keyboard that much and just wants to achieve success by holding down 1 note. But when i shorten up the attack and release, then that very quickly turns it into something that is delightful for me to play, as a keyboard player. Another thing you can do is program in something on one of the wheel controls. my 2 favorite options for this are filter cutoff (wawawawaw), and vibrato. To do a nice vibrato the way i like, set the LFO to somewhere around 4x per second, then make the LFO control the pitch up and down, then, set the wheel to increase the depth of the LFO as you push the wheel up. If you have things on the wheels then i think you're gonna have a lot of fun and be able to express yourself really well

Question: how do you make things that are meaningful without making them feel meaningless?

there is meaning laced through every fiber of our world. but it has to seemingly be balanced with non-meaning. i've learned it's best not to fight with this natural up and down flow. But if you're wondering how to get this to happen while you are actually equipped with writing tools, my suggestion for that is just gradually start using the writing tools more and more, without worrying about whether anything is 'good' yet. then one day, when you least expect it, the unpredictable flow of meaning will continue as it always does, except the tools will already be comfortable in your hands

do you think the louder you get a mix, the tighter the volume levels have to be for its elements? sometimes i want to just put a "maximizer" on my master and realize as soon as i start pumping everything, the unbalances become more noticeable, the loud start feeling louder in comparison to the mix etc. im not sure if its the maximizer, just the volume perception, or what.

i am guessing it's not working properly. if it's doing what it's supposed to, it should even out the volume. it might be just making everything louder, because the settings might not be right for your mix and you might just be hearing the 'make up gain' by default, which would just make it louder and not do anything. (this is what happened to me in the early stages). what i would suggest is to make sure there is no make up gain, then make sure the ratio is not 1:1 (make sure the first number is higher), then raise the threshold all the way up. Now it should be doing exactly nothing. then press the bypass button on and off to compare, and it should sound exactly the same. Also check to see if there is a 'reduction' monitor so you can see when it's actually doing something. So now it should be doing nothing. Now, with the bypass off (so the compressor is ON), start gradually lowering the threshold until you start to see the 'reduction' meter gradually start to light up when it hits those loud parts, and it should be tapering them down. then once you've compressed it down a little then you can raise the make up gain

how do you prime factor numbers so well? you're great at doing it

you have to check to see if each smaller prime number goes into it. to do that, you can modify the big number by small multiples of the small number, until you get it to something you recognize. most of the trick is to get the big number to even out to a multiple of 10, then you can drop the zeros and it still maintains its same status of whether or not it is divisible by the smaller prime number you're checking into it

anything can happen, but the only way you're gonna get the answers is if you can trick your brain to stop worrying about it. which gets more and more difficult the more you care. which, if you're like me, is a lot. i think rhyming the entire word all the way up to every last consonant sound usually sounds pretty bad, and tends to feel empty. it seems to feel much much more meaningful to me when only the vowel sound is the same, and the rest of the word sounds different. and in some cases i am open to using a completely different sounding word because sometimes i think that sounds the best and has the most meaningful impact. If the words rhyme too well then i think as a listener i would get the sense that the writer doesn't even care what the words mean. But if the word sounds slightly different the next time around, then you get a nice feeling of growth and change

it's like a much much more meticulous and complicated version of that. i can write much faster than i can produce, so from 2008 to 2012 there was sort of a writing epidemic going on, where i just kept writing and writing and writing. not necessarily even finishing them. so in september 2012 i started gathering a chronological list of every song or partial song i had ever written, and then i started working little bits on each one. the same list continues to this day. So when it's time to record/produce and song/video, i have an elaborate writing/selection process where i write some brand new things first, add them to the list, then go through the entire list, pick out good candidates for the next production (i usually end up choosing about 25), then i do some additional writing on some of those, then finally i make my final selection. Then i continue writing that one to completion. The idea of casually finding a song, and just thinking 'oh this is good so i'll do it' seems hilarious to me. that's just not how it works. my mind has to go to full scale war with itself to settle on a song selection

what do you call that chord when, say in the key of C, you have F in the bass and in the melody you have B (and G) resolving to A (and F)? Can you ever call that Fsus2add#11 (or #4?), also what if the 5 isn't included (is it included usually?), thabks (it's like a double suspension methinks)

Fsus2b5 is the most efficient way i can think of. If you are in a world where F2 is understood to mean Fsus2, then, F2b5 is definitely the way to go. If i were writing it on a chart for myself personally, i would say F2#4, and i know maybe that means 5 is allowed when it's not there, but, seeing that i would probably get that i'm supposed to focus on the 2 and #4. And also, if the next chord is F, then i think as a reader i'd easily pick up on the movement that's implied. As you can see, charts can be a lot of approximation and guessing games. Now that i think about it, writing words and sentences is like that too sometimes

i was doing a writing exercise where i was writing jingle videos based on old notebook entries. I would randomize a date, then look up what i had was writing or thinking about on that date. Then i would try my best to summarize musically what was happening. So i got one from the summer of 2007, i looked at the page from then, and it was really bad. very uninspired, useless in almost every way. i could tell i was feeling quite worthless on that day. I the jingle i made was "hello, i'm a piece of garbage" (not the one you are referring to), which seemed appropriate. Then, maybe a couple of selections later, just by chance, i got one from the next day immediately after that (also in the summer of 2007). And it had exactly the same sort of affliction. So i really wasn't sure what to do, because it seemed like i had already done this one. But, so often, honesty is the best answer to things, so i framed the jingle as a sequel to the previous one, doing essentially the same thing

im confused about note/note chords. would c/e be e c e g (normal c chord with an extra e below it)or e g c (flipped version of c chord)?

i would say if your chart says C/E, that means the E note is probably supposed to be a bass note. (so, probably at least an octave away from the rest of the chord. As for whether you think it's necessary to still include another E note in the midrange part of the chord, that's up to you. it can be nice to put the E in the bass and actually just play C and G in the midrange of the chord. that's a pretty nice sound that is found readily all over all types of music you've heard. you'll have to check to see which seems to sound better at that point in the song you're playing, and on the instrument you're using. If the arranger has a specific preference, then they're gonna have to tell you directly or else write out the notes in the chart

the lyrics and music are so closely linked, that quite often a lyric change means you have to change the music also. occasionally in some rare cases there might be a seamless lyric change, but that would usually only be for a word or two.
